newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Vranitzky meets Albanian parties to end deadlock.
newsitem.headline: Vranitzky meets Albanian parties to end deadlock.

text.p: European envoy Franz Vranitzky met leaders of Albanian President Sali Berisha's Democratic Party on Thursday to try to resolve a deadlock over a law for early elections in the troubled Balkan state.

The dispute between the Democrats and the rest of the nine-party National Reconciliation government over how many seats should be chosen by proportional representation is holding up a final decision on a date for the elections, agreed after riots in March and expected on June 29.
Democratic Party leader Tritan Shehu, a former foreign minister, said after meeting Vranitzky that he had suggested holding the vote two weeks earlier, on June 15.
Vranitzky, a former Austrian chancellor now acting as envoy of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), was due to meet Berisha later in the day.
It is the European envoy's third visit since widespread rioting over failed pyramid savings schemes pushed Albania to the brink of anarchy in March.
Vranitzky said he would convey to all Albanian political leaders "the expectation of the international community that they find political consensus as far as the election is concerned".

Interim Prime Minister Bashkim Fino met Vranitzky on Wednesday, shortly after the European envoy arrived on his three-day visit. Fino said he was optimistic an agreement could be reached on the electoral law.
Democratic Party leaders, who want to keep the current law in which fewer seats are decided by proportional representation, played down the importance of the new legislation.
"The electoral law is not such an essential item as the present electoral law is very democratic and it is already in force," Genc Pollo, secretary general of the Democratic Party, told reporters.
Fino, frustrated over a failure to reach a consensus on the issue after five all-party meetings, has said the government will now adopt the new law by majority and pass it to parliament for approval.
He has sought a vote of confidence from the Democratic-dominated parliament and has said the government will resign if the legislature does not pass the new law.
Shehu stressed the importance of disbanding so-called salvation committees, citizens' groups set up to restore order after the riots, that are another stumbling block to the elections.
Berisha maintains the salvation committees are working for Fino's socialists and will obstruct free and fair elections.

Fino denies his party is involved with the committees and says they should be disbanded after a date for the election is fixed. Residents of the south, where most of the committees were formed, say their influence has waned.
